there's a barbara walters special on religion on right now.  seems to be focusing a lot on atheism.  frankly, i can't believe how they're portraying them; they picked only the assholes, it seems, who say "I KNOW THERE ISN'T A GOD AND I DON'T KNOW HOW YOU COULD BELIEVE IN ONE."  they do the clever slow zoom, making them seem sinister.  now they're talking near death experiences.  a quote: "there is not proof that it doesn't exist - [so] it exists!"  pretty much sums up the special.  what a load of shit.
i'm an atheist, for a number of reasons.  for one, the presence of a "god" is something i've never felt, or at least never recognized as god.  a lot of people i know who believe cite "feeling" god's presence as a reason they believe, so there's strike one.  i also just cannot wrap my mind around it; one being being able to control everything, all knowing, all powerful.  it seems a bit fatalistic to me.  also, i feel it's limiting.  why believe in the power of god when i can believe in the power of nature, and more importantly, of myself?

back to music tomorrow, i promise.

i don't think many people read my journal, so i'll narrow it down to ten lyrics.  guess the song, get your name next to it.

1. Oh, the things we do when you're away.

2. Don't surround yourself with yourself, move on back to squares.

3. I remember a time when your cigar was ironic.

4. what's it gonna take to get disinvited?

5. this ain't no foolin' around

6. look at her laughing, like a heifer to the slaughter.

7. you could tell how you felt - you felt it

8. you're the best i'll never have

9. i know this world is killin' you

10. erogenous zones, i love you.

so i've become mostly bored with telling people my emotions, so i'm going to turn this into a music blog, talking about songs/albums i'm into at the time. to start it off, we've got Yes' "Close to the Edge." I'm only going to discuss the song, not the album, since I haven't listened enough to And You and I or closely enough to Siberian Khatru. I think this song is brilliant; plainly put, Yes' best recorded work - better than Roundabout, better than I've Seen All Good People, better than South Side of the Sky. The song is long - 18:41, and starts and ends with some synth sounds and birds chirping, which is a bit boring, but I'll be damned if it feels long. As I said, the setup can be boring, but it feels appropriate. Like Roundabout or South Side, there's a long musical interlude surrounded by chorus/verses, standard Yes fare. What I think separates this song from the others I've mentioned is just how spot on the band is on the recording. The song itself is, as expected from Yes, beautiful, but moreover, especially towards the end, it is the most adrenaline-filled, intensely climactic piece I've ever heard from them. When it starts going, the energy that Bruford and Howe especially convey is just astounding. Everything with this song seems spot on. Check it out.

my quarter was basically going nowhere until five weeks ago.  the wednesday before i left for home for the first time, i found out (in a rather surprising manner) that the girl i'd had an incredible crush on for the year before...  apparently, she was into me, too.  
in five weeks, i fell in love.  in five weeks, i remembered.  hell, in five weeks i completely forgot; i stopped comparing her to anyone in my life.  and now (of course) she's gone.  my mom could tell; my family can always see right through me.  i almost stayed for her, and i really considered doing it.  this is all vague; this all sounds like i'm in high school again, but maybe that's a good thing.  in high school, at least for some parts, i was really happy.  i wasn't grasping for happiness, wasn't trying to find it where it wasn't.  if anything, i was trying to find reasons to be unhappy and i couldn't.  
i like being happy.
more importantly, i love her.  already, i can't wait to see her again.

so i got my wii.  had to wait outside of best buy from 530 to 10 to get it, and then wait in another line to actually buy it for about half an hour.  zelda is incredible, wii sports is crazy fun.  
two weeks left of school, final week and exams, and i am having a great time of it, finally enjoying myself here.  looks like i'll be back in the spring, since i have yet to hear from maryland.  that might work pretty well for myself, actually.

last night i thought i had something really nice to write.  i've lost it.

I'm sure almost the entire internet is abuzz about this, but The Beatles - Love is pretty damn incredible.  It's a reinvention of almost every Beatles song on the album, though a few stay similar.  Really, really good.  Get it.
FURTHERMORE, Casino Royale is an incredible movie.  The more I talk about it, the more I love it.  Craig plays a brilliant Bond; he's new to the 00 rank, unsure of what to do, still figuring himself out.  It does include a particularly brutal torture scene, but goddamn.  Best Bond movie since Goldeneye.

look, i don't really care if i ever see you again.  really.  i'm over you.
that said, do we still need to act immaturely?  it's been over a fucking year.  i can see you and say hello and smile and we can exchange pleasantries without making things awkward for either one of us.  i let you (or more accurately the memory of you) rule over my life for a while.  you've stopped me from doing a lot of things.
but no, scratch that.  i stopped me.  i'm finished with that.
one more new leaf turned over.

i've been back for less time than i am usually back for breaks from school and already my dad and i are at each others' throats.  and we'd worked so hard to work it out.
this is ridiculous.
new rule!  no drunken lj entries unless i DON'T try to sound special!

Comment on this entry and I will give you a letter. Write ten words beginning with that letter in your journal, including an explanation what the word means to you and why, and then pass out letters to those who want to play along. adam gave me p parachute - one of my fondest memories of public school, way way back in 1st and 2nd grade, was playing that awesome game where you were given a big unfolded parachute and everyone waved it and you would run under all at the same time and grab the edges and hold them down and slowly the parachute would deflate. just how everything looked under that, with all those colors and the sun shining through. it was pretty. pity - such a sad word, isn't it? i used to try to get people to pity me, i think, because getting them to actually like me was far too hard. i think i've grown out of that by this time. hopefully. :) participate - something i've found myself unable to do recently in class, mostly because of this state of nasty depression i've been in recently. i don't like talking in groups anymore, it makes me nervous and i just don't express myself well anymore. oh well. parlez-vouz francais? - i don't know if i spelled that correctly, because i don't speak french. so, if you're tempted to start speaking french to me, ask that question first, then realize i will answer with 'no,' and then say whatever the hell it is in english. i'm ignorant, yes, i know. too bad. this sort of leads me to my next word... pretension - i've been using this word a lot lately, because pretension has been pretty much staring me in the face since september. i did my best to ignore it, but ugh, school is just damn full of it. oh well, i probably contribute to that. i should watch myself. pebbles - i'm running out of p words, but i could use some cereal. post fruity pebbles or post cocoa pebbles? YOUR VOTES WILL DECIDE prog rock - a certain genre of music i've been really getting into lately. king crimson, a certain bit of yes, maybe even a little bit of genesis (back when peter gabriel was still the singer). i am hovering somewhere between proud of my musical growth and ashamed. palpate - i've been reading naked lunch for class, and it's in there a few times while discussing some std. it popped into mind. paranoia - everybody's coming to get me... i get paranoid sometimes, that my friends are conspiring against me, that people are talking about me behind my back... but maybe a little bit of paranoia is healthy, yeah? predator - it was a good movie i guess. i can't think of words, dammit.

the biggest differences between chicago and home are the little things.
playing frisbee last night at 11 in the rain and the fog, i glanced up and saw the biggest, most beautiful constellation i had ever seen.  of course, the city lights are far too bright for there to be any real stars.  actually, it was just lights in the apartment building across the street, some bright, some dim, working together to create the illusion of a constellation.
for those few seconds, though, between when i saw it and when i realized what it was, i felt alright being here.  after i realized what it was, i felt homesick.
i miss the stars.

why don't you just admit how you feel?

it's warm outside (it's 65!) and i think tomorrow would be best spent playing frisbee at the point.  i love the spring, it's always a good temperature; it makes the outdoors fun.

three days until baltimore (!!!)

Mistah Kurtz - he dead I We are the hollow men We are the stuffed men Leaning together Headpiece filled with straw. Alas! Our dried voices, when We whisper together Are quiet and meaningless As wind in dry grass Or rats' feet over broken glass In our dry cellar Shape without form, shade without colour, Paralysed force, gesture without motion; Those who have crossed With direct eyes, to death's other Kingdom Remember us -- if at all -- not as lost Violent souls, but only As the hollow men The stuffed men. II Eyes I dare not meet in dreams In death's dream kingdom These do not appear: There, the eyes are Sunlight on a broken column There, is a tree swinging And voices are In the wind's singing More distant and more solemn Than a fading star. Let me be no nearer In death's dream kingdom Let me also wear Such deliberate disguises Rat's coat, crowskin, crossed staves In a field Behaving as the wind behaves No nearer -- Not that final meeting In the twilight kingdom III This is the dead land This is cactus land Here the stone images Are raised, here they receive The supplication of a dead man's hand Under the twinkle of a fading star. Is it like this In death's other kingdom Waking alone At the hour when we are Trembling with tenderness Lips that would kiss Form prayers to broken stone. IV The eyes are not here There are no eyes here In this valley of dying stars In this hollow valley This broken jaw of our lost kingdoms In this last of meeting places We grope together And avoid speech Gathered on this beach of the tumid river Sightless, unless The eyes reappear As the perpetual star Multifoliate rose Of death's twilight kingdom The hope only Of empty men. V Here we go round the prickly pear Prickly pear prickly pear Here we go round the prickly pear At five o'clock in the morning. Between the idea And the reality Between the motion And the act Falls the Shadow For Thine is the Kingdom Between the conception And the creation Between the emotion And the response Falls the Shadow Life is very long Between the desire And the spasm Between the potency And the existence Between the essence And the descent Falls the Shadow For Thine is the Kingdom For Thine is Life is For Thine is the This is the way the world ends This is the way the world ends This is the way the world ends Not with a bang but a whimper. by T.S. Eliot

a son of close friends of the family killed himself Friday.
he was 19 or 20, if I recall correctly.
RIP Steven Toth.
it's a whole different feeling when you're leaving your friends.
I drew a picture of you. It's how I see you in my dreams. It's the only way I can see you anymore.

I woke up this morning and turned on the news, saw that London had another bomb scare.  It scared the shit out of me, because Georgia is over there right now.  Unfortunately, I couldn't really check it out, but after coming home from work and e-mailing Georgia, I read around and it seems there were no injuries.  Phew.
Work is rough.  It's a pretty easy job, in that it entails sitting around on my ass most of the day, but sitting ten hours in a car is a drain on my psyche and my gas tank, neither of which are very good.  Still, it pays more than enough to cover my gas bill, so that's good.
I wrecked my knee last night.  Thanks Marc.  Hopefully it'll be better by next week or so.  
Also, I might be joining a soccer team.  I hope I do, I love to play.

This update has been brought to you by the letter Z.

So the Aquabats show was rescheduled for August 20th.  The Ottobar's block had no power.

But I met the Aquabats.  All of them, Crash, Ricky Fitness, Popeye, Jimmy the Robot, and the Bat Commander.

And David and I got filmed for the DVD, so we might be on that.

Tonight ruled.

As most, if not all of you know, we (my mother and father), along with my father's business partner Rob, have begun renting an apartment in New York City.  This past weekend, we went up there for the first time as a family.
We got down there Saturday evening after my mom and I took a train from Wilmington.  I was pretty tired, so after a quick stop at the market for some dinner, I settled down on the internet and watched Degrassi all night.  Good show.
Sunday, I met up with my friends Ian and Mer.  Ian and I met around noon at Town Hall on 43rd between 6th and 7th to pick up some tickets for a free concert the local classical station was putting on.  After that, we headed back to my apartment to bask in the glorious air-conditioning.  Later, we went to a comic book store right by the Empire State Building.  I ended up only purchasing an Aqua Teens t-shirt, but I think next time I'll get the Crisis story-arc book.  Sunday was also the day of the gay pride parade, which lasted for at LEAST six hours.  There were plenty of dance-party busses, transvestites, and one man wearing a butterfly costume.  After stopping back at the house for a quick bite, Ian and I went to Town Hall to meet up with Mer.  The concert we saw was a performance by a solo percussionist named Evelyn Glennie.  It focused mainly on marimba, though she included one recital piece for concert snare which was amazing, and included an open roll which must have lasted seven minutes, speeding up and slowing down.  With every stroke, you could hear her concentration.  The marimba things she did were equally amazing.  The most amazing thing, of course, is that she is profoundly deaf and "hears" music by feeling the vibrations.  After that, we went back home, and Ian and Mer met my family, along with Uncle Rob, his daughter Lizzy, and Lizzy's two friends.  We went to dinner at a nice Thai restaurant where I had some delicious beef with broccoli.  After that, Ian and Mer headed home, and I settled in for a final night of Degrassi.
Then we came home.  Long story short: Traffic.

I've been slowly becoming more and more aware that I can be very rude and mean to people.
Please be aware that most of the time, my rudeness and unkindness is entirely unintentional.
I don't know if it's because I've just never become properly adjusted socially, or because I am just damn ignorant of others' feelings, but honestly, to anyone I've insulted, I apologize.

I go through phases, when I get depressed, and one of those phases is a terrible feeling that in my life, I've become stuck in neutral, unable to experience anything new in my life.  It's the worst part, I think; it's not a feeling of sadness, but melancholy.  I feel like I've done everything in my life.  It's not any sort of great feeling of accomplishment, but just that I'm not going to do anything new in my life.  I stop seeing the fun in things I really do enjoy - being with my friends, my family, even the simple happiness I take in being alone.  And the worst part is, I try so hard to change things, I come up with huge, fantastical ideas and never have the drive to actually make them happen.  I start to sleep all day just trying to escape the routine of my life.  I bounce back eventually, but I end up insulting and offending my friends and family by making them think I don't appreciate them.

Please realize that I do appreciate you, all of you.  I'm truly sorry that I can be such a little bitch to you all; I treasure our time together and wouldn't trade it for the world.

NDP's prom was a great time.  Many thanks to Maria for inviting me, and for managing to convince me to actually dance a majority of the time.  

Hitchhiker's Guide was a really good movie.  It might not have been as good as the book, but I thought some of the things in it, all of which seemed to be the brainchildren of Douglas, were phenomenal.  The spaceship Heart of Gold was a beautiful, Death Star-esque globe with a wonderfully hollow center.  The Vogons were great, and all of the characters were well-played.  The chemistry between all of the actors was there, too, and it really shower.  It was very interesting to me to see the characters brought to life in a visual sense (I say that because they were all so vibrantly alive in the books), specifically Zaphod and Marvin.  Mos Def was over-the-top sometimes, and I initially was annoyed, but I think it was pretty perfect for someone with no concept of what it is to be human.

AP tests this week, after which half of my classes will be finished.  Day 4, I won't even have to go to school.  After that, it'll just be Myth, Relationships (ugh), and Latin.  Fortunately, the only class I don't like of those, and indeed the only class this year I haven't found myself enjoying, is Relationships.  We've just begun the sexuality portion of that class, which should be highly amusing, at the very least.

Girls Gone Wild seems to be the epitome of this culture's obsession with avoiding sexuality, speaking of the subject (and having just seen a commercial for said product).  Yes, it's entirely about tits and ass and all of that shit, but there isn't even a hint of real sexuality.  There's no concept of a story, even one as weak as in most pornography.  Instead, it's just a montage of girls lifting up their shirts, pulling their shorts down or their skirts up to show their thongs, or lack thereof.  They're not human.  It's like extreme slave fetish, domination to the point of a loss of identity.  Do the girls realize this?  Is that why they're okay with it?  Will their excuse simply be "Oh, I was so drunk, I wasn't myself."?

This week is NDP's prom with Maria.
Next week is three AP tests, and then those classes will be over.  After those classes, I'll only have religion, Latin, and Myth and the Hero left to take care of, and I should only have to take the religion exam.  (Thanks, by the way, Ms. Dillon, for having that wonderful exam policy.)
For the first time in a very long while, I had a nightmare the other night.  Not one of those dreams that throws you into a Dali painting, but a genuine nightmare, ghosts and all.  I woke up confused, for the first time in a very long while, as to what had really happened, and what hadn't.  It took me a good half-hour to sort it all out.
It scared me good.

Just got back from Chicago, which was an absolutely great amount of fun. Read Georgia's post, too, because she and I ended up doing a lot of things together. Some highlights, in quotation form: "It's just, it's like... this is a really hard book!" "Of course we didn't have acting competitions in New Jersey, because we realize that acting is an entirely subjective institution!" "They didn't really appreciate "Bitchcock Armadildos" very much." "I woke up, and he was at the computer, just staring at me." "I come from Ithaca, right by Cornell, so the suicide rate seems low no matter what. Plus, we don't have anything to jump off of." "Can I steal some of those from you?" "It's not really stealing if you ask, that's just getting what you ask for." "No one's ever mentioned that to me before." "Welcome to Chicago." There were so many great things about it. The classes I went to - European History and Dante's Inferno - were both amazing and didn't feel like the ninety minutes they were. The hosts were great - thanks Dave and Bobby, if you see this. I am thrilled I got in.

I am pleased to inform you that you have been admitted to the University of Chicago, Class of 2009. Congratulations! You should be proud of the accomplishments and promise that led to your selection.

We feel a particularly strong responsibility to admit students who are not only qualified but who are ready to continue the crucial business of educating themselves. You have been selected by our faculty and admissions counselours because you recognize the pleasure - the absolute joy - to be found in active, creative learning. Our decision was not based on numbers but on your achievements and your words, a difficult determination to make but one that gives proper honor to the University and you.

You have the chance to be part of a school with a glorious history and an exciting present. We look to you to help us grow, to grow with us, and to be a part of a tradition that elevates us all. Yours Truly, Theodore A. O'Neill Dean of Admissions

Dear Officer:
Your job description is "To Protect and Serve," not "To be a dick to seventeen year olds with half a gallon of gas who need to be home in a few minutes who then apologize to you and make you flip out."
Andrew
P.S. Even your tiny dick couldn't ruin my day.

Every now and then, I get this strong urge to create, and I can't.  It frustrates me that I am so fucking creatively impotent, it drives me mad that my mind can't come up with complete ideas only fragments of concepts that I know I'll never bring to fruition.  
I feel so motherfucking conflicted - on the one hand, I like where I am, I like living, simply put.  On the other hand, I can't wait till next year, till college, wherever I go.  I can't wait for the freedom and for the new people, new experiences, new opportunities that might be ahead.
And of course, when it comes to that, I get scared and nervous as I always fucking do.  Will I be able to handle it?  All of this keeps going through my head.  It's not enough to keep me up at night, not nearly enough, but every now and then, it's powerful enough to make me pause for a second and just think - what if?  I thought I'd gotten past that, past the point where I lived in the past or in the future, and to the point where I really and completely lived in the right here, right now.  I thought I'd gotten past the what if's in all aspects of my life, but every now and then something pulls me back to it.
I've been treating the people in my life pretty shitty recently, and I'd like to apologize.  There are things going on that you may or may not understand, but honestly, I do not want to talk about them.  This isn't a cry for help, this is a reason.

For any of you who haven't heard, Hunter S. Thompson, best known as the author of Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (which is best known as a movie starring Johnny Depp) shot himself in the head yesterday, causing a very quick death.

tonight has left me in a strange little mood.
the fallout show was an experience, to say the least.  Thirty or so people in one and a half cramped rooms.  I've never quite heard fallout play like that.  I liked it, a lot.

I've just come to the sudden realization that I need to get out of this place, with all of its fucking trendwhores.
The people who insist on labeling and bragging and talking about everything they do.
The people who do it all for the fucking attention, with their faux-romantic ideologies.
Do you really crave it that badly that every minute thing you kids do has to be cataloged and noticed and applauded by someone other than yourself?
I notice you, I see that shit-eating grin on your face and I hate myself for looking up and letting you win.
I hate this bullshit, and I hate that I can stare it straight in the face and not do anything about it.

Today was nice.  I bought Minish Cap, got a haircut, Ashley came over, went to Comedy Nite, and hung out in Starbucks being cool with Georgia, Maria, Megan, and David.

Note to self: Don't drink the whole sample, you just wasted a perfectly good upgrade.

Fucking EVERYONE knows Glen, man, fucking EVERYONE.

So begins the real studying for exams.
Last night, my dad and I went to DC for a night of old Blues.  Clarence Carter, Bobby Blue Bland, and B.B. King.  It was amazing, to see an 80 year old man who's been playing since his teens still love it so much to get up there and play for so long.  The stories he tells, both in and out of music, are a great experience, and if anyone ever gets the chance to see it again, you can't miss it.
Tomorrow I have AP Euro and Latin to do, Wednesday is English, and Thursday is Calc, and then begins the second semester.  I hope everything goes well.

You started being a bastard last year, you know that? You found out you were the best at something (in a pretty mediocre crowd, mind you), you found out you were the best at one thing, and you started acting like the fucking god of everything. You take everything personally, you know, and you got this fucking attitude like you deserve more respect than we give you. If anything, you deserve less respect. You're the geniune renaissance man, you think, you know something about everything: music; art; literature, you fucking name it, you know it. So how come when it comes to thinking, you fail? Just a simple question.

Well Next Tuesday, I return to Calvert Hall for my senior year, don't I? This year, I've got a bit of a challenging schedule. My three APs will either kick my ass or excite me to the point that I get an A; double Magrogan should prove... interesting; and I should have a car, enabling me to actually leave early for a change. I really don't have much to write about at the moment, though perhaps I will do a summer sum-up at a later date.

I've begun a new community, towson_politics.  You're free to join if you wish, you can figure it all out from the livejournal frontpage.  And no, it isn't to discuss in-Towson politics, it's for kids who live near, or go to school near Towson to talk politics.  I imagine I'll be one of the few conservatives there, but it's easier than debating in Ryan's journal.  Maybe we'll have a set topic every once in a while.

The next few weeks should be interesting.  Georgia leaves tomorrow for Deep Creek Lake, and Sunday Kristen leaves for two weeks to be a good person.  I will miss both of them a lot, but two weeks without the girlfriend is gonna be really really rough.  
Work fucking sucks.  My boss hates me because he rarely sees me working, which is entirely coincidence, I swear.  I'm up to my ass in files that I don't really want to finish that early.  The lab is fucking hot, too.  Work is really taking its toll, I'm hardly getting any sleep, so today I napped for three hours, prompting my mother to ask what was the matter.  That's annoying, especially since the first two times, I said nothing, and she kept asking.

I've begun my summer life as a working man, working up to 8 hours a day, five days a week. I work at GTA, GeoTechnology Associates. Basically, I work in a dirt lab, tossin' round dirt and weighing dirt, and playing with the files. I get to purge 18 or so years' worth of files this week, it'll take a while, but thank god I'm working with another person, or it would take twice as long. At least I get paid. I work with some good guys, too. The purpose of this post, however, was not to discuss my work, contrary to the contentions of the topic. The purpose was to discuss the use of the term "thrifting." While I fully enjoy shopping at thrift stores, and condone it, as it is a good way to get clothes cheap, I think calling it "thrifting" cheapens it, makes it seem different from shopping for clothes, which is what you're doing. Sure, it sounds cooler and more indie or whatever to call it thrifting, but it's really just shopping. It's just like calling something antiquing seems pretentious, it's just shopping for old shit that has no use. You don't call shopping for food fooding, and don't start now. Just call it shopping, there's no reason to point out WHERE you're shopping. I should go shower. Edit: Please note, this is not an attack on those who use the term, just the term itself.

I like Towson, when I'm with friends.
I like friends.
I like seeing friends I did not expect to see, and then spending time with them.
I like seeing friends I did expect to see, and then spending time with them.
I like making my friends laugh.
I like making my friends happy.
I like friends getting along with other friends.
I like letting my friends know that I am there for them, if the need ever arises.
I like getting new CDs, and my friend letting me listen to it when I know said friend would much rather listen to something else said friend would like more.
I like letting said friend get away with it.
I like that tomorrow, I will probably see my girlfriend.
I like that Sunday, an audial extravaganza may take place.  
I like that my friends are willing to kidnap me to hang out.
I like inventing new catch phrases.

Guess what tomorrow - a day full of things I really like.

Day one of exams, Honors World Literature and Honors Physics.
Honors World Lit wasn't too bad, the hardest question was the first one, which was basically compare the Metamorphosis and One Hundred Years of Solitude.  Then "A Doll's House," and then I did something on Goethe's Faust, which I never read, and Camus' The Myth of Sisyphus.  I think I did pretty well, I was pretty prepared, I guess.
Physics was a different story.  It's really great to arrive at the exams five minutes early to discover the calculator you put in your bookbag is no longer there, and you're completely fucked.  Thankfully, most of the math was doable without it, but I will definetely need a calculator for tomorrow, pre-calc.  At 12:30.  God dammit.

So the aunt, uncle, and cousins are visiting, and just in time for exams.  Not only do I get to commit a bit too much time to studying, but I get to have my cousins distracting me the whole time with their loud, annoying voices.  I remember when my uncle (not my aunt, mind you, she never was) was a quiet person, before they had frickin' kids and wrecked it for me, and the rest of the human race.  Thankfully, the little bastards let me sleep in.
So last night, my family, along with Katie and Kristen, went and saw Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban.  It was pretty good, I suppose.  I'm not going to say the book was better, because I don't remember the book well enough.  Katie is being looked at for a part in the fifth book as a somewhat-important character, so hooray for her.  I had a good time seeing both Katie and Kristen, and the two seem to be getting along.  They have very similar interests, which is fantastic.
I have to call my step-grandfather today before martini time so I can ask him some questions about Dubya Dubya Two.  I should get on that, martini time starts around five.

Last night, Kristen and I went to see Troy, which was alright. As a movie, it was pretty damn good, Brad Pitt is a good actor, as is Sean Bean. It kind of destroyed the plot of The Iliad, though. Paris doesn't die, and both Agamemnon and Menalaeus do. Plus, it portrayed Menalaeus as an asshole, when he was really just manipulated by his brother. Oh well. It was great spending time with Kristen. She's so much fun, so interesting... Everything about her is great, and as much as I seem like a stupid teenage kid for saying that, it's how I feel. Oh well. I rearranged my room today, something I haven't done in a while. I didn't move a whole lot around, because a lot of the stuff in my room is too heavy to move now. I did move my bed into 'summer position,' which basically means the light doesn't hit it until late in the day, so I can sleep as much as I please. Adam comes over today, which will be good fun. Two Dicks all night, but he does have to leave for church in the morning. School is going well, except for Physics. Oh well. A week or two ago, I was walking to my garage to get some groceries, and on the path to the garage/driveway/parking area, there is a motion-sensor light that doesn't always work perfectly. Being as how it was dark, I tried to get it to turn on, whch can sometimes require... effort. So, I began jumping up and down rather wildly. After a minute or two of this, my mom comes up and informs me that the light has burned out. Whoops.

My spring break has been alright, yeah. Thursday night, though actually Friday morning I suppose, I had a great conversation with someone I feel much, much closer to now. I really owe her a lot, more than I can express with just a 'thank you.' I need to figure out a way to tell her how much I appreciate it. Maybe I will make her a card. I dunno. I need to figure out what to do with my life. I'm really thinking music production is my calling... I don't know what to do about college, though. I have a lot of choices, which is not to say I'm an exceptional student or anything, there are just a lot of colleges out there. It's really scary, to be honest. I visited a few colleges this week, Fordham, NYU, and Manhattanville. Fordham seemed cool, my kinda-cousin Andrew has a lot of fun there. NYU seemed big, though the dorms were small in a cruel contrast, but they have a major which recognizes the music producer as an artist, which is tempting, and Manhattanville was just kind of... boring. I feel bad saying that, like I'm going to offend people there, but it just does not seem like the kind of environment for me. I'm sure it is great for the students who go there, though. I've hung out with Georgia a lot lately, to the point where both our parents thought we were dating. We're not. We're just good friends, and that is actually very satisfying. She's really easy to talk to, and get along with. Great fun. I think I need to get out more, to expand my circle of friends who I hang out with. I should get to that ASAP. I wish I had my license, I need to take that goddamn class. Fuck you, state of Maryland. In other news, down with democracy. I've been thinking a lot about it, and I think it is just remarkably inefficient. Though I suppose I should fear Bush's Thought Gestapo coming after me now. Look at that, I compared Bush not only to Big Brother, but to Hitler. Wow. He's not that bad, I suppose, I just don't agree with the man on a lot of fronts. I talk too much.

Today, I learned of the death of this girl's father. I went to middle school with said girl, but have not seen her since we graduated. It's not like we really hung out, or talked, or even really liked each other. We kind of co-existed. But I still can't help but feel guilty. I don't really feel sad about her father dying. I don't know if it is because I feel I no longer know the girl well, or because I've never met her father, but I really do not feel sorrow because she is in pain. I wish I did, I honestly do, but the only sorrow I feel is that her father, who was by all accounts a nice guy, has passed on because of a burst blood vessel in his brain. Am I really so callous that just because I have not talked to this girl in a while, I no longer care how she feels? She is still a person, the same as me, does she not deserve the sorrow I would give my friends? I feel like such a shitty person for this. Hm. I hate when people say they will do something, but never go through with it. Oh well, I suppose that that is one of those things that has to go on with people. Tomorrow and Thursday I will be visiting New York to see NYU and Manhattanville. Also, I will likely be picking up some deck threads. (Confused as to the meaning of deck? Pick up a copy of The Hipster Handbook at Barnes & Noble, pure genius.) My prom-thing that isn't really a prom cause I'm a junior is fast approaching. I've got too much worthless shit that I care about.

Here it is, my friends, spring break has arrived at last. So far, I spent Friday with Georgia, Saturday with my Playstation, and tomorrow will be with the family and Jesus. Who knows about the week, though Wednesday and one surrounding day will be spent in New Thom Yorke. CDs I've purchased in the past two days: Modest Mouse: Good News for People Who Love Bad News Bob Dylan: Lovesick (Victoria's Secret Exclusive - I bought a pack of gum and got it.) The Descendents: Cool to Be You (Their first recording since 96's Everything Sucks The Velvet Underground & Nico Good listening all, I am sure. Also, it should be noted that I change my music whenever I update my journal so I can seem cool. This time, however, I did not.

Colleges, colleges, colleges.  This weekend begins my college tour, which I'll be doing for most of the year.  I'm visiting Virginia Tech (Adam) Saturday and Sunday, after the ACTs.  I'll also be visiting NYU, University of Maryland College Park, Boston University, and probably a few others.  UMCP isn't really a choice of mine, but it is my safety and I have a few friends to visit there.  Hello, WillBach and Shaun.  So hopefully, I will enjoy my visit, I will get to meet a few DDR players who are much better than I will ever be.  Aside from Adam, who is already amazing, there'll be Zeus and probably MAXX PARANOIA, who I think has the dumbest name ever but who will destroy me in DDR if I ever go against him.  Do not hurt me, MAXXwell.

This week has been boringly interesting.  Many things happened, mostly crappy, but oh well.  Last Friday, my laptop had stopped working, and since it was not working any better Monday, I decided to do something about it.  The trackpad is broken, it seems, so I have to send it in, but thankfully, Apple customer support is the nicest bunch of people on the face of the earth, so they sent me a box and such to send back to them.  I must send that this weekend.  
I got my report card, and my parents were enraged at the three seventies and the three missing assignments comments.  Oh well, I don't really care, I suppose.  
I've come to realize that I have a problem with one or two of the teachers at my school.  This isn't some sort of immature "My teacher sucks," kind of thing, I can handle that, some people are more able to teach than others, and it is something I can grow to accept.  I just suppose that on a personal level, I do not get along with one or two of my teachers.  I have no problem coming to terms with the fact that I am not actually the smartest person at my school.  I am very happy to admit that I have no common sense, really, and I understand the occasional need to remind me of that, I suppose.  But it is just unneccesarily insulting to talk down to me the way one teacher at my school does.  I am unsure of what his disagreement with me is, but since we have gotten to know each other, he has never been actually kind to me, and is only on rare occasions civil.  Therefore, I try to avoid contact with this certain teacher as much as possible, just to keep tensions low.  Sometimes, however, direct contact is needed, and this very frequently ends in his becoming exasperated with me, and treating me like an idiot.  I, personally, see no need for this, and I think I may talk to him about it, especially because he is also involved in something I enjoy very much, and would hate to have my experience in it wrecked by personal disagreements with a superior.
In band news, we received our parts for the opener.  I am on rack, unfortunately.  I was really hoping I would get a core part this year, but that is not happening.  Oh well, there go my dreams of glory for my senior year.
Also, I purchased The Lonesome Crowded West.  I certainly hope it is as good as Ben claims it is, though I am sure it will not disappoint.
